dspace-development.title: Generate regularly-scheduled DataSet reports for downloading Item Bitstreams from DataSpace

comments.body:
Filtering by >1GB files required mapping bitstreams to their item_ids. This information is provided through the REST API, but did not have the ability to filter efficiently. However, the API was useful to double check the following query:

```shell
psql -c "COPY(SELECT ib.item_id, bb.bitstream_id, size_bytes FROM item2bundle ib INNER JOIN bundle2bitstream bb ON ib.bundle_id = bb.bundle_id INNER JOIN bitstream b ON bb.bitstream_id = b.bitstream_id WHERE size_bytes > 1000000000 AND deleted = 'f') to STDOUT with CSV HEADER;" > test.csv
```
...or more readable:
```sql
COPY(
SELECT ib.item_id, bb.bitstream_id, size_bytes
FROM item2bundle ib
INNER JOIN bundle2bitstream bb
ON ib.bundle_id = bb.bundle_id
INNER JOIN bitstream b
ON bb.bitstream_id = b.bitstream_id
WHERE size_bytes > 1000000000 AND deleted = 'f') to STDOUT with CSV HEADER;
```

To answer the question: "How many downloads have there been on items containing bitstreams > 1GB?" The following script was used:

```bash
psql -c "COPY(SELECT DISTINCT ib.item_id FROM item2bundle ib INNER JOIN bundle2bitstream bb ON ib.bundle_id = bb.bundle_id INNER JOIN bitstream b ON bb.bitstream_id = b.bitstream_id WHERE size_bytes > 1000000000 AND deleted = 'f') to STDOUT with CSV;" > item_ids.csv
cat item_ids.csv | while read id; do solr-count statistics "type:0 AND owningItem:$id"; done > item_stats.csv
paste -d, item_ids.csv item_stats.csv > item_ids_and_stats.csv
```
it returns the following two columns. The first column is item IDs and the second column is total number of downloads:
```csv
5215,1
5835,0
80957,33
80986,583
82991,145
84124,251
84125,1341
84458,91221
84527,1848
84571,42
84988,462
86127,59
87139,12
88126,172
88163,1142
89963,0
89967,435
90167,223
90614,0
90788,11595
93267,157
93649,727
94132,311
95791,1486
95911,256
96312,239
96991,459
97505,153
98115,243
```

Better yet, add another inner join and an awk script so that we pull in handles:

```bash
psql -c "COPY(
SELECT DISTINCT h.handle, ib.item_id
FROM handle h
INNER JOIN item2bundle ib
ON h.resource_id = ib.item_id
INNER JOIN bundle2bitstream bb
ON ib.bundle_id = bb.bundle_id
INNER JOIN bitstream b
ON bb.bitstream_id = b.bitstream_id
WHERE size_bytes > 1000000000 AND deleted = 'f')
to STDOUT with CSV;" > item_ids.csv

awk -F "\"*,\"*" '{print $2}' item_ids.csv | while read id; do solr-count statistics "type:0 AND owningItem:$id"; done > item_stats.csv
paste -d, item_ids.csv item_stats.csv > item_ids_and_stats.csv
```


```csv
88435/dsp010r967622k,84571,42
88435/dsp010v8383240,89967,435
88435/dsp010z708w530,5215,1
88435/dsp011j92gb30r,98115,243
88435/dsp011n79h6771,84124,251
88435/dsp011z40kw63j,95911,256
88435/dsp013f4628214,93267,157
88435/dsp0141687k93v,84527,1848
88435/dsp015138jh55f,90167,223
88435/dsp015d86p269k,84125,1341
88435/dsp015d86p271z,86127,59
88435/dsp017s75df850,84988,462
88435/dsp019g54xm26f,87139,12
88435/dsp01bv73c289q,82991,145
88435/dsp01cf95jd86d,80986,583
88435/dsp01dn39x4181,88163,1142
88435/dsp01dz010s83s,93649,727
88435/dsp01h415pd368,97505,153
88435/dsp01h415pd457,95791,1486
88435/dsp01jw827f34g,89963,0
88435/dsp01ks65hf84n,88126,172
88435/dsp01nz8062179,84458,91221
88435/dsp01pz50gz79z,90788,11595
88435/dsp01q524jr55d,94132,311
88435/dsp01qf85nf101,96991,459
88435/dsp01td96k493c,80957,33
88435/dsp01wp988n60t,96312,239
88435/dsp01zw12z5428,5835,0
```

The files constitute a genizah of their very own.  The directories appear to be hard-drive dumps, with haphazard directory names.  Most filenames adhere to a shelf-mark-based naming convention.  About half are tifs; the other half are .dng.

One subset of files are different. NEH_Geniza comprises 5 deliveries in six directories; some directories contains items organized by volume; each of these directories is subdivided into images of individual fragments and images of sheets.  Others are tiffs of MSS pages (bound and unbound); one directory contains images of oversized items, sub-divided into various stages of stitching. These must be processed differently from the rest.

pulfalight.title: Implements a new view for an expanded finding aid collection
Ensure that the "ask a question" form is fully accessible
Request cart Vue components need to be integrated into the Expanded Collection View
Request Cart "toggle icon" is offset from "total items indicator" in Firefox
Ensure count badge lines up next to cart
Remove child documents from document query

comments.body:
On second thought, I see there is functionality to render a minimal document for HTML for AJAX requests? Is that more important than intolerable load times? In fact, this seem obsolete as it was primarily intended for a table of contents or expanded collection view, neither of which use this functionality.

https://github.com/pulibrary/pulfalight/blob/main/spec/requests/catalog_request_spec.rb#L37
https://github.com/pulibrary/pulfalight/issues/239
https://github.com/pulibrary/pulfalight/pull/243
@eliotjordan Yeah I think that was for the old "collection context", and we have the table of contents now.
I was able to reduce the expanded view render time from 20 seconds to 5 five seconds by limiting the child fields the solr document tree requests.
